title: Communities and Connectivities: Iron Age Britons and their Continental Neighbours
descriptions:
The project "Communities and Connectivities: Iron Age Britons and their Continental Neighbours" proposes to conduct the first genome-wide ancient DNA analysis of Iron Age populations in Europe, focusing on the period from 800 BC to AD 100. The research will primarily explore the region of Britain within the wider European context, utilizing methodologies such as ancient DNA analysis, isotope analysis, osteoarchaeological approaches, and cultural archaeological approaches. 

The project aims to map genetic clusters, address population movement, explore inter-regional connectivity, examine social dynamics, investigate household compositions, identify familial relationships, analyze gender-specific mobility, and study the development of social inequalities. The scale of analysis will involve studying 1000 individuals in the UK and 250 individuals in Europe.

The expected outcomes of this research include providing a new vision of Iron Age communities and serving as a benchmark for future archaeological analyses in Europe and beyond. The interdisciplinary team brings together expertise in ancient DNA, isotope analysis, osteoarchaeology, chronological modelling, and cultural archaeology to ensure the success of the project.

Overall, this project has the potential to significantly contribute to our understanding of Iron Age populations and their interactions, shedding light on the complexities of ancient societies and providing valuable insights into the broader context of European archaeology.
